Maryland Alpha Chapter of Phi
Beta Kappa, national honorary scholastic society, will hold its formal initiation of newly-elected men at the
new Faculty Building tonight at 6:30.
The initiation will be followed by a
banquet at 7 o'clock.
Dr. Leo Wolman, Professor of Economics at Columbia University Will
be guest speaker at the banquet.
Dr. Wolman, Chief of the Research
Department of the Amalgamated
Clothing Workers of America and
author of several books on trade
unionism and economics, took his
Ph.D. at the Hopkins in 1914. His
brother, Dr. Abel Wolman, was recently a guest speaker at the Faculty
Dinner.
Thirty-one Hopkins men were
awarded the honor of election to Phi
Beta Kappa recently. Of these, fourteen were undergraduate students,
eleven graduate students in philosophy, three graduate students in medicine, one alumnus, and two members
of the academic staff.

Death Of'Billy'Steffen Brings
To Close Era In Hopkins History
Eighty-Two Year Old Chemistry Assistant Had Been Last
Link With Great Traditions Of The
"Old" University
By JEWETT GOLDSMITH
An era in the history of the
Hopkins has just closed. It ended
Monday with the death in a West
Baltimore Sanitarium of Billy
Stewert, who had been connected
with the chemistry department from
1876 until illness forced his retirement last September.
Billy, who died at the age of 82,
was a twenty-two year old carpenter
when he aided in the construction of
the first chemical laboratory the
University ever had. Upon its completion he moved in as head janitor
and was soon given charge of all
laboratory equipment and supplies.
With his wife in charge of the
litockroom his sister-in-law running a
boarding house patronized entirely
by chemistry students and he himself in charge of the laboratories,
113illy was in a position to come into
close personal contact with the great
and near-great who studied at the
Hopkins under the late Ira Remsen.
It was he who supplied the personal
human touch that became character'stic of the old Hopkins.
Memory "Phenomenal"
He had a phenomenal memory.
rhere was not a single product of
the graduate chemistry department
Whom he could not call by his first
name. Whenever he was visited by

'26 or '96) of the lab in which he used
to work and the problem which occupied him.
Such was his following, that, it is
reported by a member of the Hopkins
chemistry faculty, nearly every delegate present at a recent meeting of
the American Chemical Society at
Chapel Hill, N.C. who had ever had

He was loved by all because of
his extreme loyalty to the University.
During his last years his chief cause
for worry was the fear that he
would be relieved of his duties (made
lighter almost evely year because of
his advancing age and declining
strength) and placed on the retirement list. This would have been fatal
to Billy Stewert, for he had been
present at the birth of a university
and had watched it grow. He knew
nothing else. The Hopkins was his
entire life. To deprive him of one was
to deprive him of the other.

Crucial Election
(Continued from Page 1, Col. 5)
The President of the Student Council should be a man
with a wide knowledge of campus affairs. He must be
tolerant and broad-minded. He should represent no
clique, no fraternity hook-up.
Membership in a social fraternity is helpful because
we think that it is an important problem on the campus.
But the President of the Student Council must remember that he represents no group but the interests of the
entire student body.
He should be scholastically healthy, with a consistently satisfactory record of grades. He should not have
any other very responsible campus job.

Dear Sir:

Whose Invasion?
Tomorrow afternoon the Hopkins lacrosse team, last
receptacle of the University's athletic ambitions, will
take the field at Palmer Stadium, N. J., for a two-hour
session with the Tigers from Princeton. In anticipation
thereof, the Nims-Lgrriat's sports staff has been cudgeling its brain to bring forth the customary hyperboles
of le sperrt, like:
"JAYS INVADE THE LAIR OF THE TIGER"
Poetic justice would have dictated a Princeton foray
on Homewood. Because if there is any invasion in this
case, the honor belongs to the Tiger alone.
For the status quo is all on the side of the Hopkins.
If there has been one certainty in the topsy-turvy world
of sport, it has been the short shrift given Northern
lacrosse teams in their meetings with representatives of
the Free State. For years so far as the Hopkins has been
concerned, coaches north of the Mason-Dixon line have
been employed in the unpleasant task of breeding
cannon fodder.
So far this year the Jays have found little difficulty
In keeping this tradition alive. A squad of veterans
has easily met the challenge of teams from C. C. N. Y.,
Dartmouth, Penn and Swathmore.
But Princeton seems to be made of sterner stuff. Before succumbing in her only two defeats this season,
she gave the Baltimore Athletic Club and Mt. Washington struggles which those revered collections of oldsters
will not soon forget. If we can attach any weight to
the tales which the clubmen have brought back from
the fray, the den of the Tiger is a fearsome place,
haunted by attack men, quick of wit and stick, who
roam like wolves about the crease, and defense men
with the approximate regard for life and limb of the
protagonists in a Harlem race riot.
And so the Palmer Stadium affair should be a lively
session. For the first time the perfect Hopkins record
finds itself in peril. But that isn't all that hangs in
the balance.
So does a great tradition.

A Help For Track

Here at the Hopkins, those directing the broad interclass athletic program have drawn up a diversified list
of ball-playing activities. To fully complete this, we
would suggest that there be staged on one afternoon a
track and field festival.
It would be possible to confine a portion of the events
to non-fraternity undergraduates and the other portion
to fraternity men. There is no reason why such a venture can't become an integral part of the point scoring
system for the Turbeyville Trophy. Points can be
awarded in the usual manner of 5-3-1. And to the
winner of the entire meet, there can be added another
10 points.
A survey of schools in the metropolitan area shows
that the majority of them include a track and field day
in their schedule of interclass athletic functions. With
our track at Homewood located so ideally close, there
is little to say against this proposed notion. Track has
long held recognition as a major sport at all universities. Running and jumping were initially man's first
sports endeavor and have continued in that place.
There exists still another value in such a move. For
the past few years interest and participation in the Jay
track team has not been as high as is healthy for the
maintenance of this sport. Something should be done
to arouse student spirit from this prolonged slump. It
is felt that perhaps the introduction of track to all university men may bring about this awakening. Many
present day track luminaries were never conscious of
their abilities until they faced competition. Thus any
hidden talent would reveal itself if this proposal is
made a practice.

"The great task of man, whose
scientific power is rapidly extending
over the inanimate world, is to find
the human values which can be fitted
Into the pattern of modern life," said
Dr. Arthur H. Compton, who spoke
last Tuesday evening at the Wilson
Memorial Church under the University Lectureship. Dr. Compton is
Professor of Physics at Chicago University and Nobel prize winner in
physics.
Dr. Compton's chief contribution
to his field has been his developments
in quantum physics. In theology, he
is an exponent of the complete reconciliation between Science and religion. Dr. Compton occupied much
Of his lecture with a discussion of his
peliefs. He said, "The seat of the
controversy between Science and religion has been the emphasis which
the latter places upon the importance
of the individual man. Science—
from Copernicus to Darwin—on the
other hand has insistently pointed
out the actual, physical insignificance
of man in the universe.
The lecturer went on to stress what
he considered the dangers of man
confusing size relationships with
value. He asserted that Science in
entirely dispassionate in its regard
of the relative importance of man
and his earth. He further hit man's
conceit in considering himself of
prime importance in the scheme of
things by judging them "as naturally
biased."
Towards the close of his address,
Dr. Compton mentioned that some
high Being probably exists to whom
all purposes and value are intelligible. In this connection he accented,
"If we assume the existence of a
supremely intelligent Being in the
universe, then we must conclude that
human life is a purposeful, rather
than an accidental result of the operation of natural laws."

Set For Clash

Baseballers Determined To

TO START

RUBINGER

---Thoroughly aroused by its thus-far
none-too-enviable record of one win
against four setbacks, the Blue Jay
nine, appearing on the Haverford diamond today, will present its most determined front. The victory spirit
is especially keen for this contest
because of the severe drubbing suffered by Jay cindermen recently at
the hands (more appropriately feet)
of Haverford's track team.
Of the five games played to date,
a single triumph, at Towson's expense, and four defeats—by Loyola,
Drexel, Swarthmore, and Washington
College--are the results. But this
statement does not represent the true
merit of the Hopkins outfit. Drexel
and Washington College have as good
clubs as are to be found in any collegiate circle. Swarthmore, likewise,
may be classed among those "better"
organizations.
The Loyola affair
came at a time when the Jays were
not up to full team strength.
Blue and Black Set
The Homewood diamondiers are
well set for their coming encounter
in Philadelphia, and Coach Bob Owings is extremely optimistic. Pitcher
Len Rubinger has been well groomed
since his fruitless effort at Chestertown last Saturday, and he and the
team are anxious to redeem themselves. Iry Milberg, who has been
doing some excellent relief work lately, will be on hand for any occasion.
There has been one change that
should greatly enhance the team defense. Romanofsky, formerly an outfielder, has ben shifted to third base,
replacing Milan, who is taking over
the outer-garden duties. Romanofsky is more of the spark-plug type
of player, and he is expected to add
the extra bit of pep desirable in an
Infield. Milan is showing up well
in his new position, and the change
of scenery should favor his batting
average.
Clisham, Hartke, and Stevens first baseman, shortstop and catcher,
respectively—can be depended upon
for their usually fine performances,
while Alperstein has been improving
regularly at the keystone bag. The
outfield will line up with Carper in
center, Milan in left, and either Brayshaw or Zavertnick (who is gaining
a reputation as a ball twirler) in
right. Everybody is "rarin' to go,"
to quote co-captains Johnny Stevens
and Diz Clisham.
The probable line-up:
Romanofsky, 3b.
Stevens, c.
Clisham, lb.
Hartke, ss.
Alperstein, 2b.
Carper, cf.
Milan, If.
Brayshaw, rf.
Rubinger, p.

Maryland Alpha Chapter of Phi
Beta Kappa, national honorary scholastic society, will hold its formal initiation of newly-elected men at the
new Faculty Building tonight at 6:30.

banquet at 7 o'clock.
Dr. Leo Wolman, Professor of Economics at Columbia University Will
be guest speaker at the banquet.
Dr. Wolman, Chief of the Research
Department of the Amalgamated
Clothing Workers of America and
author of several books on trade
unionism and economics, took his
Ph.D. at the Hopkins in 1914. His
brother, Dr. Abel Wolman, was recently a guest speaker at the Faculty
Dinner.
Thirty-one Hopkins men were
awarded the honor of election to Phi
Beta Kappa recently. Of these, fourteen were undergraduate students,
eleven graduate students in philosophy, three graduate students in medicine, one alumnus, and two members
of the academic staff.

Death Of'Billy'Steffen Brings
To Close Era In Hopkins History
Eighty-Two Year Old Chemistry Assistant Had Been Last
Link With Great Traditions Of The
"Old" University
By JEWETT GOLDSMITH
An era in the history of the
Hopkins has just closed. It ended
Monday with the death in a West
Baltimore Sanitarium of Billy
Stewert, who had been connected
with the chemistry department from
1876 until illness forced his retirement last September.
Billy, who died at the age of 82,
was a twenty-two year old carpenter
when he aided in the construction of
the first chemical laboratory the
University ever had. Upon its completion he moved in as head janitor
and was soon given charge of all
laboratory equipment and supplies.
With his wife in charge of the
litockroom his sister-in-law running a
boarding house patronized entirely
by chemistry students and he himself in charge of the laboratories,
113illy was in a position to come into
close personal contact with the great
and near-great who studied at the
Hopkins under the late Ira Remsen.
It was he who supplied the personal
human touch that became character'stic of the old Hopkins.
Memory "Phenomenal"
He had a phenomenal memory.
rhere was not a single product of
the graduate chemistry department
Whom he could not call by his first
name. Whenever he was visited by

he would remind the former student,

'26 or '96) of the lab in which he used
to work and the problem which occupied him.
Such was his following, that, it is
reported by a member of the Hopkins
chemistry faculty, nearly every delegate present at a recent meeting of
the American Chemical Society at
Chapel Hill, N.C. who had ever had
any contact with thq Hopkins inquired
as to Billy's condition.
He was loved by all because of
his extreme loyalty to the University.
During his last years his chief cause
for worry was the fear that he
would be relieved of his duties (made
lighter almost evely year because of
his advancing age and declining
strength) and placed on the retirement list. This would have been fatal
to Billy Stewert, for he had been
present at the birth of a university
and had watched it grow. He knew
nothing else. The Hopkins was his
entire life. To deprive him of one was
to deprive him of the other.

The President of the Student Council should be a man
with a wide knowledge of campus affairs. He must be
tolerant and broad-minded. He should represent no
clique, no fraternity hook-up.
Membership in a social fraternity is helpful because
we think that it is an important problem on the campus.
But the President of the Student Council must remember that he represents no group but the interests of the
entire student body.
He should be scholastically healthy, with a consistently satisfactory record of grades. He should not have
any other very responsible campus job.

thereof, the Nims-Lgrriat's sports staff has been cudgeling its brain to bring forth the customary hyperboles
of le sperrt, like:
"JAYS INVADE THE LAIR OF THE TIGER"
Poetic justice would have dictated a Princeton foray
on Homewood. Because if there is any invasion in this
case, the honor belongs to the Tiger alone.
For the status quo is all on the side of the Hopkins.
If there has been one certainty in the topsy-turvy world
of sport, it has been the short shrift given Northern
lacrosse teams in their meetings with representatives of
the Free State. For years so far as the Hopkins has been
concerned, coaches north of the Mason-Dixon line have
been employed in the unpleasant task of breeding
cannon fodder.
So far this year the Jays have found little difficulty
In keeping this tradition alive. A squad of veterans
has easily met the challenge of teams from C. C. N. Y.,
Dartmouth, Penn and Swathmore.
But Princeton seems to be made of sterner stuff. Before succumbing in her only two defeats this season,
she gave the Baltimore Athletic Club and Mt. Washington struggles which those revered collections of oldsters
will not soon forget. If we can attach any weight to
the tales which the clubmen have brought back from
the fray, the den of the Tiger is a fearsome place,
haunted by attack men, quick of wit and stick, who
roam like wolves about the crease, and defense men
with the approximate regard for life and limb of the
protagonists in a Harlem race riot.
And so the Palmer Stadium affair should be a lively
session. For the first time the perfect Hopkins record
finds itself in peril. But that isn't all that hangs in
the balance.
So does a great tradition.

A Help For Track

Here at the Hopkins, those directing the broad interclass athletic program have drawn up a diversified list
of ball-playing activities. To fully complete this, we
would suggest that there be staged on one afternoon a
track and field festival.
It would be possible to confine a portion of the events
to non-fraternity undergraduates and the other portion
to fraternity men. There is no reason why such a venture can't become an integral part of the point scoring
system for the Turbeyville Trophy. Points can be
awarded in the usual manner of 5-3-1. And to the
winner of the entire meet, there can be added another
10 points.
A survey of schools in the metropolitan area shows
that the majority of them include a track and field day
in their schedule of interclass athletic functions. With
our track at Homewood located so ideally close, there
is little to say against this proposed notion. Track has
long held recognition as a major sport at all universities. Running and jumping were initially man's first
sports endeavor and have continued in that place.
There exists still another value in such a move. For
the past few years interest and participation in the Jay
track team has not been as high as is healthy for the
maintenance of this sport. Something should be done
to arouse student spirit from this prolonged slump. It
is felt that perhaps the introduction of track to all university men may bring about this awakening. Many
present day track luminaries were never conscious of
their abilities until they faced competition. Thus any
hidden talent would reveal itself if this proposal is
made a practice.

"The great task of man, whose
scientific power is rapidly extending
over the inanimate world, is to find
the human values which can be fitted
Into the pattern of modern life," said
Dr. Arthur H. Compton, who spoke
last Tuesday evening at the Wilson
Memorial Church under the University Lectureship. Dr. Compton is
Professor of Physics at Chicago University and Nobel prize winner in
physics.
Dr. Compton's chief contribution
to his field has been his developments
in quantum physics. In theology, he
is an exponent of the complete reconciliation between Science and religion. Dr. Compton occupied much
Of his lecture with a discussion of his
peliefs. He said, "The seat of the
controversy between Science and religion has been the emphasis which
the latter places upon the importance
of the individual man. Science—
from Copernicus to Darwin—on the
other hand has insistently pointed
out the actual, physical insignificance
of man in the universe.
The lecturer went on to stress what
he considered the dangers of man
confusing size relationships with
value. He asserted that Science in
entirely dispassionate in its regard
of the relative importance of man
and his earth. He further hit man's
conceit in considering himself of
prime importance in the scheme of
things by judging them "as naturally
biased."
Towards the close of his address,
Dr. Compton mentioned that some
high Being probably exists to whom
all purposes and value are intelligible. In this connection he accented,
"If we assume the existence of a
supremely intelligent Being in the
universe, then we must conclude that
human life is a purposeful, rather
than an accidental result of the operation of natural laws."

RUBINGER

---Thoroughly aroused by its thus-far
none-too-enviable record of one win
against four setbacks, the Blue Jay
nine, appearing on the Haverford diamond today, will present its most determined front. The victory spirit
is especially keen for this contest
because of the severe drubbing suffered by Jay cindermen recently at
the hands (more appropriately feet)
of Haverford's track team.
Of the five games played to date,
a single triumph, at Towson's expense, and four defeats—by Loyola,
Drexel, Swarthmore, and Washington
College--are the results. But this
statement does not represent the true
merit of the Hopkins outfit. Drexel
and Washington College have as good
clubs as are to be found in any collegiate circle. Swarthmore, likewise,
may be classed among those "better"
organizations.
The Loyola affair
came at a time when the Jays were
not up to full team strength.
Blue and Black Set
The Homewood diamondiers are
well set for their coming encounter
in Philadelphia, and Coach Bob Owings is extremely optimistic. Pitcher
Len Rubinger has been well groomed
since his fruitless effort at Chestertown last Saturday, and he and the
team are anxious to redeem themselves. Iry Milberg, who has been
doing some excellent relief work lately, will be on hand for any occasion.
There has been one change that
should greatly enhance the team defense. Romanofsky, formerly an outfielder, has ben shifted to third base,
replacing Milan, who is taking over
the outer-garden duties. Romanofsky is more of the spark-plug type
of player, and he is expected to add
the extra bit of pep desirable in an
Infield. Milan is showing up well
in his new position, and the change
of scenery should favor his batting
average.
Clisham, Hartke, and Stevens first baseman, shortstop and catcher,
respectively—can be depended upon
for their usually fine performances,
while Alperstein has been improving
regularly at the keystone bag. The
outfield will line up with Carper in
center, Milan in left, and either Brayshaw or Zavertnick (who is gaining
a reputation as a ball twirler) in
right. Everybody is "rarin' to go,"
to quote co-captains Johnny Stevens
and Diz Clisham.
The probable line-up:
Romanofsky, 3b.
Stevens, c.
Clisham, lb.
Hartke, ss.
Alperstein, 2b.
Carper, cf.
Milan, If.
Brayshaw, rf.
Rubinger, p.

Golfers Encounter
Virginians This P. M.
The Johns Hopkins golf team meets
the Virginia clubmen this afternoon
on the Rodgers Forge fairways. Up
to date the Jay squad has defeated
Haverford and the Philadelphia College of Osteopathy and lost to
Swarthmore. The team is being led
by Don Miller, Bill Wagner, Charlie
Dunning (captain), and Holt Maulsby.

Johns Hopkins will open with its
original starting line-up, now devoid
of any injuries. Naylor and Swindell
combine with Ghinger to form the defensive trio with Kahl protecting the
nets. Beeler and Enders are fighting
it out for the wing attack post with
the latter probably getting the call.
Yearley takes up the other wing post
and completes the midfield with
Hammer Himes drawing for the faceoff. Melvin, Kaufman, and Dukehart
complete the line-up at close-in
attack.
An interesting phase of the game
Is the presence of Bill Logan, the
Tiger mentor, who played with Kelso
Morrill on the Johns Hopkins Olympic
team of 1928.
